feed.title: Deno
feed.subtitle: The latest news from Deno Land Inc.

entry.title: Deno 1.45: Workspace and Monorepo Support
entry.summary: Deno 1.45 introduces workspaces and monorepo support, improved Node.js compatibility, updates to `deno install`, the new `deno init --lib` command, deprecation of `deno vendor`, Standard Library stabilization, upgrades to V8 12.7 and TypeScript 5.5.2, and more.

entry.title: Introducing KV Backup for Deno Subhosting
entry.summary: This new feature allows Subhosting users to configure their KV databases to back up data to their own S3-compatible object storage via APIs.

entry.title: A Gentle Intro to TypeScript
entry.summary: Quick, digestible bites of TypeScript goodness for Deno developers. In this first bite, we introduce TypeScript, how to add type annotations to your code and why you should.

entry.title: Announcing Hono on JSR
entry.summary: Hono, a lightweight, fast, cross-platform web framework, is now on JSR.

entry.title: How We Made the Deno Language Server Ten Times Faster
entry.summary: When a customer reported performance issues with the Deno language server, we began a performance investigation that resulted in reducing auto-completion times from 6-8 seconds to under one second in large codebases. This is how we did it.

entry.title: How the Guardian uses Deno to audit accessibility and performance across their 2.7 million articles
entry.summary: The Guardian receives over 350 million unique page views. Learn how Deno helps the Guardian maximize web performance and adhere to accessibility standards to retain and grow their readership.

entry.title: Introducing More Flexible Domain Association for Deno Subhosting
entry.summary: This new update simplifies programmatically managing custom domains, wildcard domains, subdomains for different deployments, and more.

entry.title: The stabilization process of the Standard Library has begun
entry.summary: The Deno Standard Library is going to reach 1.0.0 shortly. We hope you try RC versions of the packages and give us feedback!

entry.title: Deno 1.44: Private npm registries, improved Node.js compat, and performance boosts
entry.summary: Deno 1.44 adds support for private npm registries, gRPC connections, improved Node.js compat with initial Next.js support, and significant performance improvements.

entry.title: How we built a secure, performant, multi-tenant cloud platform to run untrusted code
entry.summary: When building a modern cloud platform to securely run untrusted code, it can be difficult to balance cost and performance. Here’s how we built Deno Deploy and Deno Subhosting.

entry.title: The Deno Standard Library is now available on JSR
entry.summary: The Deno Standard Library has moved to JSR, supporting SemVer ranges in imports and compatibility with Node.js, Cloudflare Workers, and more.

entry.title: How to document your JavaScript package
entry.summary: Writing good JSDocs for your JavaScript package is critical to its success. Here are some best practices for creating docs that helps your users be successful.

entry.title: Your Low Code Solution Needs an Escape Hatch
entry.summary: A low-code solution is a simple way to offer some flexibility for your users. However, to accommodate further customization (especially for enterprise users), you should have an “escape hatch” — simple, code-level customization. Here are three product scenarios and where an escape hatch makes most sense.

entry.title: Deno 1.43: Improved Language Server performance
entry.summary: Deno 1.43 enhances productivity with a faster language server, improved npm compatibility, a new `deno serve` subcommand, URL.parse() API, and announcements regarding Deno 2.

entry.title: How Slack used Deno to save months of engineering effort in launching their new platform
entry.summary: Learn how building with Deno helped Slack launch their new development platform in weeks and not months.

entry.title: JSR Is Not Another Package Manager
entry.summary: JSR introduces a new way to share JavaScript and TypeScript code across platforms, focusing on simplifying distribution without replacing existing package managers.

entry.title: Announcing the Hookdeck SDK on JSR
entry.summary: Hookdeck, an event gateway for distributed and async architecture, now has an SDK on JSR.

entry.title: Announcing the Neon Serverless Driver on JSR
entry.summary: Neon, a performant, edge-compatible, serverless Postgres driver, arrives on JSR.

entry.title: An intro to TSConfig for JavaScript Developers
entry.summary: TypeScript, one of the fastest growing languages, helps JavaScript developers improve code quality and productivity. But getting started can be challenging. Here's an introduction to TSConfig.

entry.title: How we built JSR
entry.summary: A modern JavaScript registry needs to be fast, reliable, and be as simple as possible for end users. Here's how we built JSR.

entry.title: How Netlify used Deno Subhosting to build a successful edge functions product
entry.summary: Learn why Netlify chose Deno Subhosting over building their own solution with AWS Lambda to offer a successful edge functions product within weeks.

entry.title: Introducing Simpler Project Creation in Deno Deploy
entry.summary: Introducing a more simplified project creation flow in Deno Deploy, including seamless CI/CD setup, a more transparent build and deployment step, and more.

entry.title: Deno 1.42: Better dependency management with JSR
entry.summary: Deno 1.42 revolutionizes dependency management with the seamless integration of JSR, enhancing Node/npm compatibility and introducing significant performance improvements.

entry.title: Introducing deployctl, the command line interface for Deno Deploy
entry.summary: Deno Deploy’s command line interface, deployctl, is the simplest way to deploy your projects to the cloud. Here’s how to do it.

entry.title: Introducing JSR - the JavaScript Registry
entry.summary: The JavaScript Registry (JSR) is a TypeScript-first, ESM-only module registry designed for the entire JavaScript ecosystem. Use JSR modules from Deno and npm-based projects. JSR is free and open source. Available today in public beta.

entry.title: How to add Monaco to a Next.js app and securely run untrusted user code
entry.summary: Enabling your users to deploy and run code can make your platform more useful. Here's a guide to building a platform that deploys and runs untrusted user code via a browser IDE with Monaco, Next.js, and Subhosting.

entry.title: Survey Results and Roadmap
entry.summary: You answered our survey and we listened. Here’s what we’re working on currently and what you can expect from Deno next.

entry.title: Deno 1.41: smaller deno compile binaries
entry.summary: We've roughly halved the size of `deno compile` binaries, added official Linux ARM64 builds, continued to land Node.js compatibility improvements, and more.

entry.title: Webhooks suck, but here are alternatives
entry.summary: Webhooks, originally proposed as a way to consume asynchronous feeds, became the one-size-fits-all solution for integrating cloud software. Here’s why we think there’s a better solution.

entry.title: Introducing Deno Deploy onboarding tutorials
entry.summary: We revamped Deno Deploy’s onboarding to show you how easy it is to use Deno’s cloud primitives in your projects.

entry.title: Deno in 2023
entry.summary: 2023 marked a significant step towards our vision of radically simplifying web development. Here are the biggest updates and what’s coming up next.

entry.title: Using Deno Subhosting vs. AWS Lambda to Run Untrusted User Code
entry.summary: Which technology is best for building a deployment platform for running third party code? Let's dive into the key differences in feature set, billing model, and performance.

entry.title: Deno 1.40: Temporal API
entry.summary: Deno 1.40 introduces the Temporal API, TC39 decorators, and a range of deprecations and stabilizations, along with improvements in Node.js compatibility, LSP, diagnostics, and handling of unstable features, paving the way for a seamless upgrade to Deno 2.

entry.title: Build Your Own Cloud IDE with the Subhosting API
entry.summary: This tutorial will show you how to build a simple cloud IDE using the Deno Subhosting API.

entry.title: Build a Cloud IDE for the Deno Subhosting Hackathon
entry.summary: Details, prizes, submission guidelines, resources, and more about the Deno Subhosting Hackathon.

entry.title: Run a Node project with Deno and win prizes in the #NodeToDenoChallenge
entry.summary: We've made a ton of improvements to our Node and npm compatibility this past year. Here's a chance for you to experience those improvements and win some prizes.

entry.title: Getting Started with the OpenAI SDK for Deno
entry.summary: Learn to use text completions, image generation, image analysis, and more features of OpenAI using their official Deno SDK.

entry.title: Deno 1.39: The Return of WebGPU
entry.summary: We've re-added WebGPU, added new deno coverage reporters, made substantial Node.js compatibility improvements, and more.

entry.title: Deno KV vs. Cloudflare Workers KV, Upstash Redis, AWS DynamoDB, and Google Firestore
entry.summary: We compare Deno KV to other serverless data stores on performance, price, developer experience, and more.

entry.title: Use Deno KV in Node with the new official npm package
entry.summary: Access our zero config distributed database, Deno KV, in your Node projects with our new npm package.

entry.title: Build Real-time Applications with the new "watch" API in Deno KV
entry.summary: Detecting changes in Deno KV with `kv.watch` makes it easier to build real-time applications like newsfeeds, analytics, multi-user collaboration tools, and more.

entry.title: Manage your Deno Deploy and Deno Subhosting projects with Terraform
entry.summary: Terraform is a popular tool used to safely and predictably provision and manage infrastructure in any cloud. Here’s how you could use Terraform to manage your Deno Deploy or Deno Subhosting projects.

entry.title: Fresh 1.6: Tailwind CSS plugin, simplified typings and more
entry.summary: Discover new improvements in Fresh 1.6 that simplify your project and make it speedier.

entry.title: Announcing Deno Cron
entry.summary: `Deno.cron` allows you to easily create scheduled jobs and is available on Deno Deploy. Here's how it works.

entry.title: How security and tenant isolation allows Deno Subhosting to run untrusted code securely
entry.summary: Deno Deploy and Deno Subhosting was designed with security and tenant isolation in mind. Here's how it works.

entry.title: How Brazil's top ecommerce platform used Deno Subhosting to drive 5x faster page load speeds
entry.summary: Learn how using Deno improves the performance of Deco.cx's clients storefronts and increase page load speeds by 5x.

entry.title: Deno Subhosting: the easiest and most secure way to run untrusted multi-tenant code
entry.summary: Subhosting is a new way to leverage Deno Deploy's fast, scalable multi-tenant v8 isolate cloud to run your users code securely.

entry.title: Announcing self-hosted Deno KV, continuous backups, and replicas
entry.summary: Deno KV is now even more flexible and powerful with self-hosted options, replicas, and S3 and GCS continuous backup support.

entry.title: Deno 1.38: HTML doc generator and HMR
entry.summary: Deno 1.38 ships with HTML doc output, hot module replacement, improved Node.js compatibility by allowing you to use your own `node_modules` folder, and more.

entry.title: Fresh 1.5: Partials, client side navigation and more
entry.summary: Discover new improvements in Fresh 1.5 that makes your site quicker to load and comes with several improvements to make authoring complex projects easier.

entry.title: Announcing Deno Queues
entry.summary: Introducing Deno Queues - zero config, scalable messaging with a guaranteed at-least-once delivery. This new primitive builds on the foundation set by Deno KV, and is available today in the Deno JavaScript runtime and Deno Deploy.

entry.title: Register for Deno Fest Tokyo, October 20th 2023
entry.summary: Join us to learn about the past, present, and future of Deno as we co-host Deno Fest in Tokyo on October 20th!

entry.title: Deno 1.37: Modern JavaScript in Jupyter Notebooks
entry.summary: Deno 1.37 ships with a Jupyter notebook integration and improved VSCode and LSP features.

entry.title: The State of Web Frameworks on Deno
entry.summary: With npm compatibility in Deno improving, and npm specifiers now available on Deno Deploy, there are more options than ever to build web apps on Deno. Let's explore some options, including Fresh, SvelteKit, Nuxt/Vue, Astro, and beyond.

entry.title: Deno KV internals: building a database for the modern web
entry.summary: How we built a performant, scalable, ACID-compliant, JavaScript-native database on FoundationDB.

entry.title: Announcing native npm support on Deno Deploy
entry.summary: Deno Deploy becomes the first isolate serverless platform to natively support more than two million modules on npm.

entry.title: Deno KV is in Open Beta
entry.summary: Deno KV, the easiest way to add a strongly consistent database to your app, is now in open beta.

entry.title: Build a Cross-Platform CLI with Deno in 5 minutes
entry.summary: Here's how Deno's built-in tools and APIs make it easy to build a CLI and distribute it to all major platforms.

entry.title: August 22nd, 2023 Deno Deploy Post-mortem
entry.summary: Post-mortem report for the Deploy outage on August 22nd, 2023.

entry.title: Fresh 1.4 – Faster Page Loads, Layouts and More
entry.summary: Discover new improvements in Fresh 1.4 that makes your site quicker to load and comes with several improvements to make authoring complex projects easier.

entry.title: Node.js's Config Hell Problem
entry.summary: Why a Next.js project has over 30 configuration files and what we can do to avoid it.

entry.title: Deno 1.36: More flexible security and expanded testing APIs
entry.summary: Deno 1.36 introduces new runtime security options plus expanded testing and benchmarking APIs.

entry.title: dnt — the easiest way to publish a hybrid npm module for ESM and CommonJS
entry.summary: How to write your module with modern tooling and transform it with `dnt` to support CommonJS, ESM, browsers, Deno, Node.js, TypeScript, and more.

entry.title: How the creator of Homebrew simplifies distributing software with tea and Deno
entry.summary: Deno is a critical part of distributing our own software and also helping our users manage their dependencies.

entry.title: Build and Ship Astro Sites with Deno and Deno Deploy
entry.summary: Learn how to build and deploy static and server-rendered apps with Astro on Deno and Deno Deploy.

entry.title: Fresh 1.3 – Simplified Route Components and More
entry.summary: Explore the key improvements in Fresh 1.3: streamlined route components, enhanced error handling, updated linting rules, and multi-island exports. This release also supports the stable Deno.serve API, making Deno projects more efficient and manageable.

entry.title: Deno 1.35: A fast and convenient way to build web servers
entry.summary: Deno.serve() is stable, support for key npm packages, and more.

entry.title: June 25th, 2023 Deno Deploy Postmortem
entry.summary: Post-mortem report for the Deploy outage on June 25th, 2023.

entry.title: CommonJS is hurting JavaScript
entry.summary: How CommonJS became Node's module system, ESM solved modules for the browser, and why supporting both slows down the JavaScript ecosystem.

entry.title: Announcing SOC 2 Compliance
entry.summary: What SOC 2 compliance for security, availability, and confidentiality means for Deno.

entry.title: Fresh 1.2 – welcoming a full-time maintainer, sharing state between islands, limited npm support, and more
entry.summary: Learn what new features the 1.2 release brings and about the future of Fresh.

entry.title: Announcing the Deno KV Hackathon
entry.summary: Rules, categories, prizes, and more about the Deno KV Hackathon.

entry.title: The State of Edge Functions 2023: The Year of Globally Distributed Apps
entry.summary: More developers are hosting entire apps at the edge and other major takeaways from the 2023 State of Edge Functions report.

entry.title: How to Build a CRUD API with Oak and Deno KV
entry.summary: Learn how to use secondary indexes, atomic transctions, and more with Deno KV in this introductory tutorial.

entry.title: Node.js built-ins on Deno Deploy
entry.summary: You can now use Node.js built-in modules like `node:http` on Deno Deploy, allowing you to run existing Node.js apps at the edge.

entry.title: Deno 1.34: deno compile supports npm packages
entry.summary: This update augments compatibility with npm and Node.js, incorporates glob support, and enhances TLS certificates with IP addresses. It also brings forth improvements to the configuration, language server, APIs, and updates to V8 and TypeScript.

entry.title: May 23rd, 2023 Deno Deploy Postmortem
entry.summary: Post-mortem report for the Deploy and Subhosting outage on May 23rd, 2023.

entry.title: How immutable scripts in Deno allow Windmill.dev (YC S22) to build production-grade ops
entry.summary: We chose Deno for its low cold start times, ability to execute untrusted code securely, and ease in creating shareable, immutable scripts.

entry.title: Build your own ChatGPT-style doc search with Fresh, OpenAI, and Supabase
entry.summary: Learn how to setup a customized ChatGPT-style doc search and work with the OpenAI Chat-GPT3 API.

entry.title: Roll your own JavaScript runtime, pt. 3
entry.summary: We'll create and load a snapshot of our custom JavaScript runtime to optimize startup time.

entry.title: Announcing Deno KV
entry.summary: Introducing Deno KV, a global key-value database for effortless stateful app development on Deno Deploy, offering seamless integration, strong consistency, and versatility.

entry.title: Deno 1.33: Deno 2 is coming
entry.summary: Deno 1.33 is a step towards our next major release, with improved LSP support, enhanced Node.js compatibility, and more.

entry.summary: What islands are, what they're not, and how they work.

entry.summary: The second half in our series of how to get up and running with Deno and Express quickly.

entry.title: Announcing Deno SaaSKit: an open-source SaaS template built with Fresh
entry.summary: Built on Fresh, SaaSKit combines the best developer experience with a performant user experience to help you start your SaaS fast.

entry.summary: Deno 1.32 brings major improvements to deno compile, Node.js compatibility, Web APIs, and more.

entry.title: Why We Added package.json Support to Deno
entry.summary: The most recent release brought some significant changes in the form of better Node and NPM compatibility with package.json support. This prompted questions from our users about whether our core priorities have shifted.

entry.summary: How to setup a REST API using Express and TypeScript in minutes.

entry.title: Introducing the Annual State of Edge Functions Survey
entry.summary: Together we can identify current and upcoming trends as well as common frustrations to better understand how to best use this nascent technology.

entry.title: You Don't Need a Build Step
entry.summary: The build step helps Node.js/npm run in the browser, optimize end-user performance, etc. But long build times limit productivity. With modern tooling, do we still need a build step?

entry.title: Deno 1.31: package.json support
entry.summary: Deno 1.31 adds support for package.json, stabilizes Node-API, Deno.Command API, adds `node:v8` module, and more.

entry.summary: We’ve got Q&A highlights from our last two live events and updates about Office Hours going forward.

entry.summary: We'll implement `fetch`, read command line arguments, and add native support for TypeScript and TSX.

entry.summary: A brief history about server-side rendering and why it's the right approach for modern web development.

entry.summary: Deno 1.30 supports built-in Node modules, deno.json is an import map, deno fmt can format without semicolons, and more...

entry.summary: Deno 1.29 ships with many npm compatibility improvements, lots of quality of life improvements and TypeScript 4.9

entry.title: Deno 1.11 Release Notes
entry.summary: The Deno 1.11 release adds new web APIs, resolves long standing issues, and improves editor experience.

entry.title: Deno 1.10 Release Notes
entry.summary: Deno 1.10 improves the built-in test runner, adds support for Web Storage API, structured clone, and more.

entry.title: Deno 1.9 Release Notes
entry.summary: Deno 1.9 adds a new native HTTP/2 web server, a vastly improved op infrastructure, import completions in the LSP, an interactive permission prompt, blob url support.

entry.title: Announcing the Deno Company
entry.summary: We have raised money to enable the millions of web programmers out there to maximally leverage their craft.

entry.title: March 2 incident update
entry.summary: Post-mortem report for the 98 minute service outage on March 2, 2021.

entry.title: Deno 1.8 Release Notes
entry.summary: Deno 1.8 adds experimental support for the WebGPU API, adds support for importing private modules, stabilizes import maps, revamps coverage tooling, adds ICU to provide internationalization out of the box, and a whole lot more.

entry.title: Deno 1.7 Release Notes
entry.summary: Deno 1.7, one of our largest releases to date, adds cross compilation and 60% smaller binaries for deno compile, a DNS resolver API, support for data URLs in import statements and web workers, and much more.

entry.title: Deno in 2020
entry.summary: Retrospect of what happened in Deno in 2020

entry.title: Deno 1.6 Release Notes
entry.summary: Deno 1.6 adds the ability to build your Deno projects into fully standalone, self-contained executables with `deno compile`. The release also introduces a built-in LSP for editor integrations, and experimental Apple Silicon support.

entry.title: Deno 1.5 Release Notes
entry.summary: Deno 1.5 improves `deno bundle` with support for tree shaking and a 15x speed improvement. This release also adds the `alert`, `confirm`, and `prompt` APIs and enhances the REPL.

entry.title: Deno 1.4 Release Notes
entry.summary: Deno 1.4 adds support for the web standard WebSocket API, deno run --watch, and integrated test coverage. This is the largest feature release yet.

entry.title: Updates to deno.land/x
entry.summary: Design considerations and changes for the new code hosting service.

entry.title: Deno 1.0
entry.summary: Dynamic languages are useful tools. Scripting allows users to rapidly and succinctly tie together complex systems and express ideas without worrying about details like memory management or build systems.
